justification: The article notes that clinicians commonly ask patients "to rate our pain on a simple 0-10 scale ranging from 'no pain' to 'most pain imaginable'," indicating this numeric scale is used to quantify pain intensity.

Figure 1A description says participants "separately rated the intensity and unpleasantness" of thermal pain, showing that the same 0-10 numeric rating procedure is also applied to the unpleasantness component.

The text emphasises that "pain is based entirely on patients' subjective ratings" and that "A person's report of an experience as pain should be respected," identifying self-report ratings as the measurement method.

Slimani et al. "evaluated the participants' willingness to accept monetary rewards paired with different levels of painful electrical stimulation, and estimated the utility function of pain from the points of indifference (50% probability of accepting a specific offer)," showing this choice task operationalises the utility function.

measured_by: Power model fitted to pain ratings across graded shocks
justification: Park et al. "fitting a power model to pain ratings obtained as participants received shocks of increasing intensity" derived an individual stimulus-response function, indicating the construct is measured via that power-function fit to rating data.
